variant.question: Which option most accurately describes essential aerodrome information?

options.text: Any information to ensure safe operation of an aircraft on the movement area.
Specific information about an intended flight or portion of a flight.
Aeronautical publications on requirements regarding the use of the aerodrome.
Elements of the special position report to be transmitted to the aerodrome information service.

variant.question:
D-CURE receives the following information from the tower; "Runway 10 in use, wind 110 degrees, 4 knots, clouds and visibility OK, QNH 1009, temperature 6 degrees, dew point 2 degrees".
What is the correct read-back?
You are in aircraft D-CURE. What is the correct read back to the following message "Runway in use 10, Wind 130/10kts, Braking action poor, QNH 1008"
An aircraft reports long final for runway 27. Tower replies "continue approach runway 27, wind 180 at 15kt". What does it mean?

options.text: Landing clearance should be expected later.
ATC expected it to be in due time.

variant.question: What is the correct way to transmit the wind vector and speed "170 degrees, 18 knots, gusting 30 knots" in radiotelephony?

options.text: Wind one seven zero degrees one eight knots gusting three zero knots.
Wind one hundred and seventy degrees eighteen knots gusting thirty knots.
Wind one hundred and seventy degrees one eight knots gusting three zero knots.
Wind one seven zero degrees eighteen knots gusting maximum thirty knots.

variant.question: Runway Visual Range (RVR) is measured in

"G-ABCD, Runway 10 in use, wind 360° / 11 kts, visibility **1200**, QNH **1006**"
How would you respond to this message?

options.text: Runway one zero, QNH one zero zero six, G-ABCD.
QNH one zero zero six, G-ABCD.
QNH one zero zero six, wind 360/11.

variant.question: Which of the following elements of an AIREP may be omitted from the standard position report?(i) Estimated time of arrival(ii) Aircraft identification(iii) Endurance(iv) Wind(v) Flight level or altitude(vi) Next position and ETA(vii) Air temperature(viii) Position

The following elements of an AIREP may be omitted from the standard position report:(i) Estimated time of arrival 
 (ii) Aircraft identification 
 (iii) Endurance 
 (iv) Wind 
 (v) Flight level or altitude 
 (vi) Next position and ETA 
 (vii) Air temperature 
 (viii) Position
When all runways at an airport are affected by wind shear, how is it reported on a METAR?

options.text: WS ALL RWY + ICAO Airport Code
WS + Runway Designator for each runway

variant.question:
ATC transmits the following message:"D-CURE, Runway 10 in use, wind 360/11 visibility 1200 metres, QNH 1006".
 What is the correct readback from D-CURE?

options.text: Runway 10 in use, wind 360/11 visibilty 1200 metres QNH 1006. D-CURE.

variant.question: In aerodrome weather reports, the term 'CAVOK' indicates that the visibility is or greater than

options.text: 10000 m, and the lowest visibility is not reported
and no clouds below 10000 ft / 3000 m or below the highest MSA, whichever is greater
and there is no weather of significance to aviation.
5000 m, and the lowest visibility is not reported

variant.question:
In aerodrome meteorological reports, cloud base information (e.g
BKN040) is measured above.

An aerodrome will report an estimate of braking action on a runway, and may also report the measured friction coefficient
 Which of the following could a pilot expect as a report?

Wind shear has been recorded on all runways at an aerodrome
What supplementary information do you expect to see in the aerodrome`s latest METAR?

options.text: WS ALL RWY ICAO designator for airport

variant.question:
You are approaching UUEE (Moscow Sheremetyevo) airport, and you ask the controller for the latest RVR. 
The latest METAR is UUEE 291200Z 14006G11MPS 0600 R14/1400U FG SCT010 OVC 020 03/M04 Q1003.
Provided there has been no significant change in the visibility, what would you expect to hear from ATC?

options.text: RVR runway 14, 1400 metres, will rise within the next 2 hours.

variant.question:
On final approach to land in moderate rain, ATC transmits the following message pertinent to the landing runway
  '?Runway report at 1243 UTC, runway 34, water up to 3 millimetres.' 

What does the pilot expect to hear afterwards??

options.text: Estimated surface friction medium to good.

variant.question: In METAR weather reports, the wind is given in degrees true. The wind as reported by the tower for take-off and landing is
When the term 'CAVOK' is used in an aviation routine weather report (METAR), what are the values of visibility and cloud?

options.text: Visibility 10 km or more, no cloud below 5000 feet/GND.
Visibility 10 km or more, no cloud below 1500 feet/GND.
Visibility more than 5000 m, no cloud below 1500 m/GND.
Visibility more than 8 km, no cloud below 3000 feet/GND.

variant.question:
Approaching Brussels international Airport, you receive the following ATIS: “Brussels Information V, Met Report time **1150**, expect ILS approach, runway in use 25L and 25R, Wind variable, 3 knots, visibility 4 km, mist, clouds scattered 400 ft, broken 2 600 feet, temperature 6, dewpoint 5, QNH **1010** hPa, Trend: NOSIG, Information V out:”
Which of the following METAR is included in the current ATIS?

options.text: EBBR 311150Z VRB03KT 4000 BR SCT004 BKN026 06/05 Q1010 NOSIG=
EBBR 1150Z 00003KT 4000 FG SCT040 BKN260 M06/M05 Q1010 NOSIG=
EBBR 311150 36003KT 4KM BR SCT040 BKN260 06/05 Q1010 NOSIG=
EBBR 311150Z VRB03KT 4000 -FG SCT004 BKN026 06/05 Q1010 NOSIG=

variant.question: The latest METAR reports: Wind 130°/ 5 kts, visibility 4000m, showers and rain, cloud, scattered CB's 2000ft, temperature 10° dew point 3°, QNH 995. Which of the following answers will generate an immediate update to the METAR.
In a runway report, what does friction coefficient 0.45? mean?

After requesting departure information on an airport where no ATIS is provided, the following information is transmitted:FASTAIR 345, DEPARTURE RUNWAY 32, WIND 290 DEGREES 4 KNOTS, QNH 1022, TEMPERATURE 10, DEWPOINT 5, RVR 550 METRES, TIME 27. What is the unit used to report the air temperature in this meteorological report?
How is temperature reported in a METAR?
CAVOK may be used in place of visibility, weather and cloud, provided that visibility is ___ or more; there is no cloud below ___ or MSA whichever is the ___ and no significant weather phenomena.
According to ICAO Annex 3, which unit is used in a METAR for providing wind speed information?

What is the surface wind at Lisbon according to this METAR?
LPPT 150505Z 11006KT 9999 BKN016 M09/M16 Q1006 NOSIG
A wind of 160 degrees, 18 knots, gusting to 30 knots is transmitted as...

options.text: Wind one six zero degrees one eight knots gusting three zero knots.
Wind one hundred and sixty degrees eighteen knots gusting to thirty knots.
Wind one six zero degrees eighteen knots gusting three zero knots.
Wind from hundred and sixty at eighteen knots gusting to thirty knots.

variant.question: The aerodrome weather report includes data on the cloud ceiling (e.g. BKN040). The reference for this vertical distance is...

An aircraft is on the final approach and the pilot intends to land. There is moderate rain. With regards to the runway condition, ATC transmits "...runway report at 11:25 UTC, runway 26, water up to 3 millimetres...". What kind of information should the pilot expect to hear subsequently?

options.text: Estimated braking action medium to good.

variant.question:
Which of the following correctly translates data from the METAR of Lisbon aerodrome given below?
LPPT **150505**Z **11006KT** **9999** BKN016 M09/M16 **Q1006** NOSIG =

options.text: Report time is 05:05 UTC, dew point is minus 16°C, QNH is 1006 hPa
Wind comes from 110 degrees true, QNH is 9 hPa less than ISA, no significant changes forecast
The temperature is minus 9°C, report time is 15:05 PM, clouds are 5-7/8 at 1 600 ft
Temperature is 16 degrees below ISA, visibility is at least 10 km, QNH is 1006 hPa

variant.question: In aerodrome meteorological reports, cloud base information (e.g. BKN040) is measured above....
What is the wind reported in this METAR LPPT 150505Z 21010KT 9999 BKN016 M09/M16 Q1006 NOSIG=?

You're flying to your destination and are concerned that there might be low clouds over the airport by the time you'll arrive, and therefore may need to divert. How would you get the weather from your destination airport? ETA in one hour.

options.text: Use the VOLMET for the latest METAR.
Ask the controller on the current frequency if he could update you with the latest TAF for your destination airport.
Rely on the TAF issued prior to departure 5 hours ago.
Tune the ATIS for the destination airport and listen out.

variant.question: In METAR and SPECI reports, the wind direction is reported in degrees true. The wind passed by the tower to aircraft for landing or take-off purposes is reported in degrees..
In METAR and SPECI reports, the wind direction is reported in degrees true. The wind passed by the tower to aircraft for landing or take-off purposes is reported in degrees...
The following is a METAR:EGLL080120Z 21010KT 9999 SCT030 07/04 Q1023 NOSIG=The wind is reported as..

options.text: wind direction 210 degrees true and speed of 10 knots.
wind direction 210 degrees magnetic and speed of 10 statute miles per hour.
wind direction 210 degrees true and speed of 10 statute miles per hour.
wind direction 210 degrees magnetic and speed of 10 knots.

variant.question:
Before departure you have been informed of changing weather conditions at the destination airport.
During the flight in the cruise, with approximately 500 nm to go, you want to check the destination weather. This information could be obtained through...

options.text: D-ATIS by using Satcom and data link equipment such as ACARS.
ATIS using the designated frequency of an airport en-route, on Very High Frequencies (VHF).
the scheduled VOLMET on Super High Frequencies (SHF).

variant.question:
Which answer decodes the following METAR correctly?
CYWG **172000Z** **30015G25KT** 3/4SM R36/**4000FT**/D 00/M02 BLSN BKN008 QNH **1020**

options.text: ...time 20:00 UTC, wind (true) 300°/15 kt, gusts max 25 kt, visibility 3/4 statute miles, RVR runway 36 4 000 ft (decreasing tendency), blowing snow, clouds broken at 800 ft, QNH 1 020 hPa
...time 20:00 UTC, wind (magnetic) 300°/15 kt, gusts max 25 kt, visibility 3/4 statute miles, RVR runway 36 4 000 m (from taxiway D), blowing snow, clouds broken at 8 000 ft, QNH 1 020 hPa
...time 20:00 LMT, wind (magnetic ) 300°/15 kt, gusts min 25 kt, visibility 3/4 statute miles, RVR runway 36 4 000 ft (decreasing tendency), blowing snow, clouds broken at 800 ft, QNH 1 020 hPa
...time 17:20 UTC, wind (true) 300°/15 kt, gusts max 25 kt, visibility 3/4 statute miles, RVR runway 36 4 000 ft, blowing snow, clouds broken at 800 m

variant.question:
Information about an aerodrome with an ATIS is also included in the list of VOLMET reports
The QNH is transmitted in

options.text: both the ATIS and the VOLMET reports.
neither the ATIS nor the VOLMET report.

variant.question: The pilot of an aircraft during an approach to land reports severe turbulence between FL 100 and FL 70. This would be classified as...
